{{featured list}} {{Infobox bibliography | Author = Amir Hamzah | Image =Amir Hamzah portrait edit.jpg | ImageSize =200px | Caption =[[Amir Hamzah]], undated | Alt =A portrait of a man looking forward | Book =1 | BookLink =Books | Article =12 | ArticleLink =Articles | Story =4 | StoryLink =Stories | 1Option =3 | 1OptionName =Poetry collections | 1OptionLink =Poetry collections | 1OptionColor =#99CCFF | 2Option =50 | 2OptionName =Original poems | 2OptionLink =Original poems | 2OptionColor =#4682b4 | 3Option =44 | 3OptionName =Translated poems | 3OptionLink =Translated poems | 3OptionColor =#FFCCFF | 4Option =18 | 4OptionName =Original lyrical prose | 4OptionLink =Original lyrical prose | 4OptionColor =turquoise | 5Option =1 | 5OptionName =Translated lyrical prose | 5OptionLink =Translated lyrical prose | 5OptionColor =#00bfff | 6Option =1 | 6OptionName =Translated books | 6OptionLink =Translated books | 6OptionColor =#FF7518 }} Indonesian author [[Amir Hamzah]] (1911–46) wrote 50 [[poem]]s, 18 pieces of [[prose poetry|lyrical prose]], 12 [[Article (publishing)|articles]], 4 [[short story|short stories]], 3 [[poetry collection]]s, and 1 [[book]]. He also translated 44 poems, 1 piece of lyrical prose, and 1 book. The majority of Amir's original poems are included in his collections ''[[Njanji Soenji]]'' (1937) and ''[[Boeah Rindoe]]'' (1941), both first published in the literary magazine ''[[Poedjangga Baroe]]''. His translated poems were collected in ''Setanggi Timoer'' (1939). In 1962 documentarian [[HB Jassin]] compiled all of Amir's remaining works – except the book ''Sastera Melajoe Lama dan Radja-Radja'nja'' – as ''Amir Hamzah: Radja Penjair Pudjangga Baru''.{{sfn|Jassin|1962|p=41}} Born in [[Langkat Regency|Langkat]] to [[Malay people|Malay]] nobility, Amir completed his education at schools run by the [[Dutch East Indies|Dutch colonial government]] in several cities on [[Sumatra]] and [[Java]].{{sfn|Language Center, Amir Hamzah}} By 1928 he had enrolled in a [[Meer Uitgebreid Lager Onderwijs]] (junior high school) in the colonial capital of Batavia (now [[Jakarta]]); he wrote his first poems during this period.{{sfn|Jassin|1962|pp=8–9}} His first published works, poems entitled "Maboek..." ("Nauseous...") and "Soenji" ("Silent"), appeared in the March 1932 issue of the magazine ''[[Timboel]]''; by the end of the year he had published his first short stories and lyrical prose, some in ''Timboel'' and some in the magazine ''[[Pandji Poestaka]]''.{{sfn|Jassin|1962|pp=211–219}} One of these works, a lyrical prose piece entitled "Poedjangga Baroe" ("New Writer"), was meant to promote the magazine of the same name that Amir established in collaboration with [[Armijn Pane]] and [[Sutan Takdir Alisjahbana]].{{sfn|Foulcher|1991|pp=14–17}} The magazine, first released in July 1933, published the vast majority of Amir's writings; most were written before 1935, then published later. Forced to return to Langkat and marry in 1937, Amir became a representative of the nascent national government after the proclamation of Indonesian independence in 1945. The following year he was captured, detained, and later executed during a [[Communist Party of Indonesia|Communist Party]]-led revolution;{{sfn|Language Center, Amir Hamzah}} his last writing, a [[Literary fragment|fragment]] from his 1941 poem "Boeah Rindoe", was later found in his cell.{{sfn|Jassin|1962|p=214}} His earliest poems followed the conventions of traditional ''[[pantun]]s'', including a four-line structure and [[rhyming couplets]].{{sfn|Teeuw|1980|p=130}} Later works departed from this traditional structure, although Jassin considers Amir to have maintained an unmistakably Malay style of writing.{{sfn|Jassin|1962|p=15}} Themes in his work varied: ''Boeah Rindoe'', chronologically the first anthology written, was filled with a sense of longing and loss, while works in ''Njanji Soenji'' tended to be distinctly religious.{{sfn|Balfas|1976|pp=62–64}} Amir received wide recognition for his poems; Jassin dubbed him the "King of the ''Poedjangga Baroe''-era Poets",{{sfn|Jassin|1962|loc=cover}} while Dutch scholar of Indonesian literature [[A. Teeuw]] described Amir as the only international-class Indonesian poet from before the [[Indonesian National Revolution]].{{sfn|Teeuw|1980|p=123}} The following list is divided into tables based on the type of works contained within. The tables are initially arranged alphabetically by title, although they are also sortable. Titles are in the [[Van Ophuijsen Spelling System|original spelling]], with a literal English translation underneath. Untitled works are recorded with their first words in parentheses. Years given are for the first publication; later reprintings are not counted. Unless otherwise noted, this list is based on the one compiled by {{harvtxt|Jassin|1962|pp=211–219}}. __NOTOC__ ==Books== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders unsortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ The books of Amir Hamzah |- ! scope="col" style="width:20em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:8em;" | Year of Publication ! scope="col" style="width:12em;"| Publisher ! scope="col" style="width:20em;"|Note(s) |- ! scope="row" | ''Sastera Melajoe Lama dan Radja-Radja'nja''

"Descend Again" | {{dts|November 1937}} | ''[[Poedjangga Baroe]]'' |- |} ==Translated poems== [[File:Dufu.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A portrait of a man looking forward|Hamzah translated a poem by Chinese poet [[Du Fu]].]] [[File:Caga no Chiyo standing beside a well.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A scroll showing a woman standing beside a well|Hamzah translated a poem by Japanese poet [[Fukuda Chiyo-ni]], known for her [[haiku]]s.]] [[File:Rabindranath Tagore in 1909.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A profile picture of a man with a long beard|Hamzah translated two poems by [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel Prize]]-winning writer [[Rabindranath Tagore]].]] [[File:Kuniyoshi Utagawa, Yamabe no Akahito, famous poet.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A woodcarving showing a man in a blue kimono looking up|Hamzah translated a work by Japanese poet [[Yamabe no Akahito]].]] {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ The translated poems of Amir Hamzah |- ! scope="col" style="width:20em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:8em;" | Month of first publication !scope="col" style="width:12em;" | Publication ! scope="col" style="width:20em;" class="unsortable" |Note(s) |- ! scope="row" |{{hs|"Adam Dibentoek Toehan dengan Emboen Tjinta"}}("Adam Dibentoek Toehan dengan Emboen Tjinta")

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} {{Distinguish|Anti-Japaneseism}} '''Anti-Japanese sentiment''' (also called '''Japanophobia''', '''Nipponophobia'''{{harvnb|Emmott|1993}} and '''anti-Japanism''') involves the hatred or fear of anything Japanese. Its opposite is [[Japanophilia]]. ==Overview==

Anti-Japanese sentiments range from [[wikt:animosity|animosity]] towards the [[Government of Japan|Japanese government]]'s actions and [[Contempt|disdain]] for Japanese culture to [[racism]] against the [[Japanese people]]. Sentiments of dehumanization have been fueled by the [[American propaganda during World War II#Anti-Japanese|anti-Japanese propaganda]] of the [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] governments in [[World War II]]; this propaganda was often of a racially disparaging character. Anti-Japanese sentiment may be strongest in [[People's Republic of China|China]], [[North Korea]], and [[South Korea]],{{cite web |url=http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/articles/views_on_countriesregions_bt/366.php?lb=btvoc&pnt=366&nid=&id|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716022940/http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/articles/views_on_countriesregions_bt/366.php?lb=btvoc&pnt=366&nid=&id|dead-url=yes|archive-date=16 July 2011|title=World Publics Think China Will Catch Up With the US—and That's Okay |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=7 March 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/articles/views_on_countriesregions_bt/168.php |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060409190445/http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/articles/views_on_countriesregions_bt/168.php |archivedate=9 April 2006 |title=Global Poll Finds Iran Viewed Negatively - Europe and Japan Viewed Most Positively |publisher=World Public Opinion.org |accessdate=7 March 2010 |deadurl=yes }}{{Cite journal |url = http://www.globescan.com/news_archives/bbccntryview/backgrounder.html |title = POLL: Israel and Iran Share Most Negative Ratings in Global Poll |publisher = BBC World Service |year = 2007 |accessdate = 13 April 2008 |ref = harv |postscript = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080330071133/http://www.globescan.com/news_archives/bbccntryview/backgrounder.html |archivedate = 30 March 2008 |deadurl = yes |journal = |df = dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://pewglobal.org/reports/pdf/260.pdf |format=PDF |title=24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey |date=12 June 2008 |publisher=The Pew Global Attitudes Project |accessdate=28 June 2008 |ref=harv |postscript=| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704015500/http://pewglobal.org/reports/pdf/260.pdf| archivedate= 4 July 2008 | deadurl= no}} due to atrocities committed by the Japanese military.{{Failed verification|date=June 2008}} In the past, anti-Japanese sentiment contained innuendos of Japanese people as [[Barbarian|barbaric]]. Following the [[Meiji Restoration]] of 1868, Japan was intent to [[Westernization|adopt Western ways]] in an attempt to join the West as an industrialized imperial power, but a lack of acceptance of the Japanese in the West complicated integration and assimilation. One commonly held view was that the Japanese were evolutionarily inferior. {{harv|Navarro|2000|loc=[https://www.msu.edu/~navarro6/srop.html#U.S. "... a date which will live in infamy"]}} Japanese culture was viewed with suspicion and even disdain. While passions have settled somewhat since Japan's surrender in World War II, tempers continue to flare on occasion over the widespread perception that the Japanese government has made insufficient penance for their past atrocities, or has sought to whitewash the history of these events.{{Cite journal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/223038.stm |title=Scarred by history: The Rape of Nanjing |date=11 April 2005 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=13 April 2008 |ref=harv |postscript=}} Today, though the Japanese government has effected some [[Japanese war crimes#Compensation|compensatory measures]], anti-Japanese sentiment continues based on historical and nationalist animosities linked to [[Empire of Japan|Imperial Japanese]] [[Japanese militarism|military aggression]] and [[Japanese war crimes|atrocities]]. Japan's delay in clearing more than 700,000 (according to the Japanese Government{{Cite journal |url=http://www.mofa.go.jp/announce/announce/1999/12/1224.html |title=Budget for the Destruction of Abandoned Chemical Weapons in China |publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan |date=24 December 1999 |accessdate=28 June 2008 |ref=harv |postscript=| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080625111242/http://www.mofa.go.jp/announce/announce/1999/12/1224.html| archivedate= 25 June 2008 | deadurl= no}}) pieces of life-threatening and environment contaminating [[Chemical weapons#China|chemical weapons]] buried in China at the end of World War II is another cause of anti-Japanese sentiment. Periodically, individuals within Japan spur external criticism. Former Prime Minister [[Junichiro Koizumi]] was heavily criticized by South Korea and China for annually paying his respects to the war dead at [[Yasukuni Shrine]], which enshrines all those who fought and died for Japan during World War II, including 1,068 [[International Military Tribunal for the Far East|convicted war criminals]]. Right-wing nationalist groups have produced history textbooks whitewashing Japanese atrocities,{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/features/jan-june05/textbooks_4-13.html |title=China Says Japanese Textbooks Distort History |publisher=pbs.org Newshour |date=13 April 2005 |accessdate=13 April 2008 |ref=harv |postscript=}} and the recurring controversies over these books occasionally attract hostile foreign attention. Some anti-Japanese sentiment originates from business practices used by some Japanese companies, such as [[Dumping (pricing policy)|dumping]]. ==Region-based Japanophobia== ===United States=== {{Main|Anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States}} ====Pre-20th century==== In the [[United States]], anti-Japanese sentiment had its beginnings well before the Second World War. As early as the late 19th century, Asian immigrants were subject to racial prejudice in the United States. Laws were passed that openly discriminated against Asians, and sometimes Japanese in particular. Many of these laws stated that Asians could not become citizens of the United States and could not hold basic rights, such as owning land. These laws were greatly detrimental to the newly arrived immigrants, since many of them were farmers and had little choice but to become migrant workers. Some cite the formation of the [[Asiatic Exclusion League]] as the start of the anti-Japanese movement in California.{{Cite book |author=Brian Niiya |title=Japanese American history: an A-to-Z reference from 1868 to the present |edition=illustrated |publisher=Verlag für die Deutsche Wirtschaft AG |year=1993 |isbn=978-0-8160-2680-7 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=QZg6Ft_jvJ0C&pg=PA37#PRA1–PA37,M1 37], [https://books.google.com/books?id=QZg6Ft_jvJ0C&pg=RA1–PA103 103–104] |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QZg6Ft_jvJ0C |ref=harv |postscript=}} ====Early 20th century==== [[File:San Francisco Chinatown Welcome.jpg|thumb|Young China Club warning to American visitors against buying Japanese goods in San Francisco's Chinatown c. 1940]] Anti-Japanese racism and [[Yellow Peril]] in California had intensified after the Japanese victory over the [[Russian Empire]] in the [[Russo-Japanese War]]. On 11 October 1906, the San Francisco, California Board of Education had passed a regulation whereby children of Japanese descent would be required to attend racially segregated separate schools. At the time, Japanese immigrants made up approximately 1% of the population of California; many of them had come under the treaty in 1894 which had assured free immigration from Japan. The invasion of China in 1931 and the conquest of [[Manchuria]] was roundly criticized in the US. In addition, efforts by citizens outraged at Japanese atrocities, such as the [[Nanking Massacre]], led to calls for American economic intervention to encourage Japan to leave China; these calls played a role in shaping American foreign policy. As more and more unfavorable reports of Japanese actions came to the attention of the American government, embargoes on oil and other supplies were placed on Japan, out of concern for the Chinese populace and for American interests in the Pacific. Furthermore, the European American population became very pro-China and anti-Japan, an example being a grass-roots campaign for women to stop buying silk stockings, because the material was procured from Japan through its colonies. When the [[Sino-Japanese War (1937-1945)|Second Sino-Japanese War]] broke out in 1937, Western public opinion was decidedly pro-China, with eyewitness reports by Western journalists on atrocities committed against Chinese civilians further strengthening anti-Japanese sentiments. African American sentiments could be quite different than the mainstream, with organizations like the [[Pacific Movement of the Eastern World]] (PMEW) which promised equality and land distribution under Japanese rule. The PMEW had thousands of members hopefully preparing for liberation from white supremacy with the arrival of the [[Japanese Imperial Army]]. ====During World War II==== [[File:Alaska Death Trap.jpg|left|upright|thumb|An American propaganda poster - "Death-trap for the Jap."]] [[File:JapaneseAmericanGrocer1942.jpg|left|upright|thumb|A Japanese American unfurled this banner the day after the Pearl Harbor attack. The man was later detained nonetheless. This [[Dorothea Lange]] photograph was taken in March 1942, just prior to the [[Japanese American internment]].]] The most profound cause of anti-Japanese sentiment outside of Asia had its beginning in the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]]. The Japanese attack propelled the United States into World War II. The Americans were unified by the attack to fight against the [[Empire of Japan]] and its allies, the [[Nazi Germany|German Reich]] and the [[Kingdom of Italy]]. The surprise attack at [[Naval Station Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]] prior to a [[declaration of war]] was presented to the American populace as an act of treachery and cowardice. Following the attack many non-governmental "[[Jap hunts|Jap hunting]] licenses" were circulated around the country. ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine published an article on how to tell a Japanese from a Chinese person by the shape of the nose and the stature of the body. {{cite journal | editor-last =Luce | editor-first=Henry | editor-link =Henry Robinson Luce | date = 22 December 1941 | title = How to tell Japs from the Chinese | journal = Life | volume = 11 | issue = 25 | pages = 81–82 | publisher = Time Inc. | location = Chicago | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Y04EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA11&dq=life%20magazine%20back%20issues%20Dec%2022%201941&pg=PA81#v=onepage&q= | accessdate = 19 February 2010 | ref =harv }} Japanese conduct during the war did little to quell anti-Japanese sentiment. Fanning the flames of outrage were the treatment of American and other [[POW|prisoners of war]] (POWs). Military-related outrages included the murder of POWs, the use of POWs as slave labor for Japanese industries, the [[Bataan Death March]], the [[kamikaze]] attacks on Allied ships, and atrocities committed on [[Wake Island]] and elsewhere. U.S. historian James J. Weingartner attributes the very low number of Japanese in U.S. POW compounds to two key factors: a Japanese reluctance to surrender and a widespread American "conviction that the Japanese were 'animals' or 'subhuman' and unworthy of the normal treatment accorded to POWs."{{harvnb|Weingartner|1992|p=55}} The latter reasoning is supported by [[Niall Ferguson]], who says that "Allied troops often saw the Japanese in the same way that Germans regarded Russians [sic] — as [[Untermensch]]en."Niall Fergusson, "Prisoner Taking and Prisoner Killing in the Age of Total War: Towards a Political Economy of Military Defeat", ''War in History'', 2004, 11 (2): p.182 Weingartner believes this explains the fact that a mere 604 Japanese captives were alive in Allied POW camps by October 1944. Ulrich Straus, a U.S. [[Japanology|Japanologist]], believes that front line troops intensely hated Japanese military personnel and were "not easily persuaded" to take or protect prisoners, as they believed that Allied personnel who surrendered, got "no mercy" from the Japanese.[https://books.google.com/books?id=x1dQwuiEU3UC&pg=PA206&lpg=PA206&dq=%22japanese+pows%22+american+hands&source=web&ots=Jy7xIG7C1S&sig=J2I027gBjV9cqjD7t3h1-FiQW3o#PPA116,M1 Ulrich Straus, ''The Anguish Of Surrender: Japanese POWs of World War II'' (excerpts)] Seattle: University of Washington Press, 2003 {{ISBN|978-0-295-98336-3}}, p.116 Allied soldiers believed that Japanese soldiers were inclined to feign surrender, in order to make surprise attacks. Therefore, according to Straus, "[s]enior officers opposed the taking of prisoners[,] on the grounds that it needlessly exposed American troops to risks ..." [[File:Salvage Scrap propaganda poster crop2.jpg|thumb|upright|An American propaganda poster from World War II produced under the [[Works Progress Administration]].]] An estimated 112,000 to 120,000 Japanese migrants and [[Japanese American]]s from the West Coast were [[Japanese American internment|interned]]{{Citation needed|date=November 2015}} regardless of their attitude to the US or Japan. They were held for the duration of the war in the inner US. The large Japanese population of Hawaii was not massively relocated in spite of their proximity to vital military areas. A 1944 [[opinion poll]] found that 13% of the U.S. public were in favor of the [[Genocide|extermination]] of all Japanese.{{Harvnb|Bagby|1999|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Yns2vRoMEDAC&pg=PA135 135]}}{{cite journal |title=Public Opinion Polls on Japan |author= N. Feraru |journal=Far Eastern Survey |volume=19 |number=10 |date=17 May 1950 |pages=101–103 |publisher=Institute of Pacific Relations |jstor=3023943 |doi=10.1525/as.1950.19.10.01p0599l}} [[Daniel Goldhagen]] wrote in his book "So it is no surprise that Americans perpetrated and supported mass slaughters - Tokyo's firebombing and then nuclear incinerations - in the name of saving American lives, and of giving the Japanese what they richly deserved."{{cite book |title=Worse Than War: Genocide, Eliminationism, and the Ongoing Assault on Humanity |first=Daniel Jonah |last=Goldhagen |publisher=PublicAffairs |year=2009 |isbn=0-7867-4656-4 |page=201 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dRys8UlV02AC&pg=PA201 }} =====Decision to drop the atomic bombs===== {{See also|Debate over the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki}} Weingartner argues that there is a common cause between the mutilation of Japanese war dead and the decision to bomb Hiroshima and Nagasaki.{{harvnb|Weingartner|1992|pp=55–56}} According to Weingartner both were partially the result of a dehumanization of the enemy, saying, "[T]he widespread image of the Japanese as sub-human constituted an emotional context which provided another justification for decisions which resulted in the death of hundreds of thousands."{{harvnb|Weingartner|1992|p=67}} On the second day after the Nagasaki bomb, Truman stated: "The only language they seem to understand is the one we have been using to bombard them. When you have to deal with a beast you have to treat him like a beast. It is most regrettable but nevertheless true".{{harvnb|Weingartner|1992|p=54}}Weingardner further attributes the Truman quote to Ronald Schaffer, {{Harvnb|Schaffer|1985|p=171}} ====Since World War II==== In the 1970s and 1980s, the waning fortunes of heavy industry in the United States prompted layoffs and hiring slowdowns just as counterpart businesses in Japan were making major inroads into U.S. markets. Nowhere was this more visible than in the automobile industry, where the lethargic [[Big Three (automobile manufacturers)|Big Three automobile manufacturers]] ([[General Motors Corporation|General Motors]], [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], and [[Chrysler Corporation|Chrysler]]) watched as their former customers bought Japanese imports from [[Honda]], [[Subaru]], [[Mazda]], and [[Nissan]], a consequence of the [[1973 oil crisis|1973]] and [[1979 energy crisis]]. (When Japanese automakers were establishing their inroads into the USA and Canada Isuzu, Mazda, and Mitsubishi had joint partnerships with a Big Three manufacturer (GM, Ford, and Chrysler) where its products were sold as [[captive import|captives]]). The anti-Japanese sentiment manifested itself in occasional public destruction of Japanese cars, and in the 1982 [[murder of Vincent Chin]], a [[Chinese American]] beaten to death when he was mistaken to be Japanese. Other highly symbolic deals — including the sale of famous American commercial and cultural symbols such as [[Columbia Records]], [[Columbia Pictures]], [[7-Eleven]], and the [[Rockefeller Center]] building to Japanese firms — further fanned anti-Japanese sentiment. Popular culture of the period reflected American's growing distrust of Japan.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} Futuristic period pieces such as ''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' and ''[[RoboCop 3]]'' frequently showed Americans as working precariously under Japanese superiors. The film ''[[Blade Runner]]'' showed a futuristic Los Angeles clearly under Japanese domination (with a Japanese majority population and culture), perhaps a reference to the alternate world presented in ''[[The Man in the High Castle]]'' written by [[Philip K. Dick]], the same author on which the film was based, in which Japan had won World War II. Criticism was also lobbied in many novels of the day. Author [[Michael Crichton]] wrote ''[[Rising Sun (novel)|Rising Sun]]'', a [[murder mystery]] (later made into a [[Rising Sun (film)|feature film]]) involving Japanese businessmen in the U.S. Likewise, in [[Tom Clancy]]'s book, ''[[Debt of Honor]]'', Clancy implies that Japan's prosperity is due primarily to unequal trading terms, and portrays Japan's business leaders acting in a power hungry cabal. As argued by Marie Thorsten, however, Japanophobia mixed with Japanophilia during Japan's peak moments of economic dominance during the 1980s. The fear of Japan became a rallying point for techno-nationalism, the imperative to be first in the world in mathematics, science and other quantifiable measures of national strength necessary to boost technological and economic supremacy. Notorious "Japan-bashing" took place alongside the image of Japan as superhuman, mimicking in some ways the image of the [[Soviet Union]] after it launched the first [[Sputnik]] satellite in 1957: both events turned the spotlight on American education. American bureaucrats purposely pushed this analogy. In 1982, Ernest Boyer, a former U.S. Commissioner of Education, publicly declared that, "What we need is another Sputnik" to re-boot American education, and that "maybe what we should do is get the Japanese to put a Toyota into orbit."{{Harvnb|Thorsten|2012|p=150n1}} Japan was both a threat and a model for human resource development in education and the workforce, merging with the image of Asian-Americans as the "model minority." Both the animosity and super-humanizing which peaked in the 1980s, when the term "Japan bashing" became popular, had largely faded by the late 1990s. Japan's waning economic fortunes in the 1990s, known today as [[Lost Decade (Japan)|the Lost Decade]], coupled with an upsurge in the U.S. economy as the Internet took off largely crowded anti-Japanese sentiment out of the popular media. ===China=== {{Main|Anti-Japanese sentiment in China}} [[File:Japanese-and-dogs-are-not-allowed statement from a restaurant in Higher Education Mega Center 2007.jpg|upright|thumb|Poster outside of a restaurant in [[Guangzhou]], China]] Anti-Japanese sentiment is felt very strongly in China and distrust, hostility and negative feelings towards Japan, Japanese people and culture is widespread in China. Anti-Japanese sentiment is a phenomenon that mostly dates back to modern times (post-1868). Like many Western powers during the era of imperialism, Japan negotiated treaties that often resulted in the annexation of land from China towards the end of the Qing Dynasty. Dissatisfaction with Japanese settlements and the [[Twenty-One Demands]] by the Japanese government led to a serious [[boycott of Japanese products]] in China. Today, bitterness in China persists"[https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-25411700 China and Japan: Seven decades of bitterness]". BBC News, 13 February 2014, accessed 14 April 2014 over the atrocities of the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] and Japan's post-war actions, particularly the perceived lack of a straightforward acknowledgment of such atrocities, Japanese government employment of known past war criminals, and Japanese historic revisionism in textbooks. From elementary school, children are taught about Japanese war crimes in detail, for example, thousands of children are brought to the [[Museum of the War of Chinese People's Resistance Against Japanese Aggression]] in Beijing by their elementary schools to view photos of war atrocities, such as exhibits of records of Japanese military forcing Chinese workers into wartime labour,"[http://www.1937china.org.cn/wmskz/shaiww/wwshiliao/20140407/20516.shtml]" the [[Nanking Massacre]],"[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/photo/2014-02/27/c_133147912.htm People visit Museum of War of Chinese People's Resistance Against Japanese Aggression in Beijing]". Xinhuanet, 27 February 2014, accessed 14 April 2014 and the issues of [[comfort women]]. After viewing the museum, the children's hatred of the Japanese people was reported to increase significantly. Despite the time that has passed since the end of the Second World War, discussions about the Japanese conduct can still evoke powerful emotions today, in part because most Japanese are aware of what happened but their society has never engaged in the type of introspection common in Germany after the Holocaust.Matthew Forney, "[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1139759,00.html Why China Loves to Hate Japan]". Time Magazine, 10 December 2005., accessed 25 October 2008 Hence, the usage of Japanese military symbols are still controversial in China, such as the incident of Chinese pop singer [[Zhao Wei]] seen wearing a Japanese War Flag dress for a fashion magazine photo shoot in 2001."[http://www.china.org.cn/english/23647.htm Chinese Pop Singer Under Fire for Japan War Flag Dress]". China.org, 13 December 2001., accessed 14 April 2014 Huge responses were seen on the Internet; a public letter from a Nanking Massacre survivor was sent demanding a public apology, and the singer was even attacked."[https://books.google.com/books?id=KtgYJI0Lo4AC&pg=PA102&lpg=PA102&dq=zhao+wei+japanese+flag+feces&source=bl&ots=CRAdExEV_y&sig=NI7X1qZFQ0qKfVhb88o-rZLUGmo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uJZMU_WPBKTG2wXxloGACA&ved=0CEcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=zhao%20wei%20japanese%20flag%20feces&f=false Chinese Media]". Lee Chin-Chuan, 2003., accessed 14 April 2014 According to a 2017 BBC World Service Poll, only 22% of Chinese people view Japan's influence positively, with 75% expressing a negative view, making China the most anti-Japanese nation in the world.{{cite web |url=https://www.globescan.com/images/images/pressreleases/bbc2017_country_ratings/BBC2017_Country_Ratings_Poll.pdf |title=2017 BBC World Service poll}} ====Anti-Japanese film industry==== Anti-Japanese sentiment can be seen in anti-Japanese war films currently produced and displayed in mainland China. More than 200 anti-Japanese films were made in China in 2012 alone.{{cite news|last=Lague |first=David |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/25/us-china-japan-specialreport-idUSBRE94O0CJ20130525 |title=Special Report: Why China's film makers love to hate Japan |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=19 October 2013 |date=25 May 2013}} In one particular situation involving a more moderate anti-Japanese war film, the government of China banned the 2000 film, "Devils at the Doorstep", because it depicted a Japanese soldier being friendly with Chinese villagers.{{cite news|last=Forney |first=Matthew |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1139759,00.html |title=Why China Bashes Japan |publisher=TIME |date=10 December 2005 |accessdate=19 October 2013}} ===Korea=== {{Main|Anti-Japanese sentiment in Korea}} The issue of anti-Japanese sentiment in Korea is complex and multi-faceted. Anti-Japanese attitudes in the Korean Peninsula can be traced as far back as the [[Wokou|Japanese pirate raids]] and [[Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598)]], but are largely a product of the [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese occupation of Korea]] from 1910–1945, and subsequent revisionism in history textbooks used in Japan's educational system after World War II. Today, issues of [[Japanese history textbook controversies]], Japanese policy regarding World War II, and [[Japanese-Korean disputes#Geographic disputes|geographic disputes]] between the two countries perpetuate this sentiment, and these issues often incur huge disputes between Japanese and South Korean Internet users.{{cite news|url=http://www.munhwa.com/news/view.html?no=2007050801032630065004|accessdate=8 May 2008|title=Munhwa Newspaper (in Korean)}} South Korea, together with mainland China, may be considered as among the most intensely anti-Japanese societies in the world.{{cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=016&aid=0000181991|date=8 May 2008|title=60th Anniversary of Independence. Half of 20s view Japan as a distant neighbor. [오늘 광복60년 20대 절반 日 여전히 먼나라]|accessdate=29 April 2012|work=Herald media(헤럴드 경제)|language=Korean|author1=Chun Chang-hyeop (전창협)|author2=Hong Seung-wan(홍승완)}} Among all the countries which participated in BBC World Service Poll in 2007 and 2009, South Korea and People's Republic of China were the only ones whose majorities rated Japan negatively.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/pdf/mar07/BBC_ViewsCountries_Mar07_pr.pdf |title=Israel and Iran Share Most Negative Ratings in Global Poll |work=BBC World service poll |page=9 |date=March 2007 |accessdate=29 April 2012 |quote=The two exceptions to this positive reputation for Japan continue to be neighbours China and South Korea, where majorities rate it quite negatively. Views are somewhat less negative in China compared to a year ago (71%[2006] down to 63%[2007] negative) and slightly more negative in South Korea (54%[2006] to 58%[2007] negative). |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071005042050/http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/pdf/mar07/BBC_ViewsCountries_Mar07_pr.pdf |archivedate=5 October 2007 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/pdf/feb06/ViewsCountries_Feb06_quaire.pdf|title=BBC World Service Poll: Global Views of Countries, Questionnaire and Methodology|date=February 2006|accessdate=29 April 2012|page=9|work=Program on International Policy Attitudes(PIPA)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329035815/http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/pdf/feb06/ViewsCountries_Feb06_quaire.pdf|archivedate=29 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} ===Taiwan=== [[File:2012 Anti-Japan demonstrations7.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators in Taiwan host signs telling "Japanese devils" to "get out" of the [[Senkaku Islands]] following an [[Senkaku Islands dispute|escalation in disputes]] in 2012.]] During the [[2005 anti-Japanese demonstrations]] in East Asia, Taiwan remained noticeably quieter than the PRC or Korea, with Taiwan-Japan relations regarded at an all-time high. The [[KMT]] majority-takeover in 2008 followed by a boating accident resulting in Taiwanese deaths has created recent tensions, however. Taiwanese officials began speaking out on historical territory disputes regarding the Diaoyutai/Senkaku Islands, resulting in an increase in at least perceived anti-Japanese sentiment.Various, Editorials. The Yomiuri Shimbun, 18 June 2008. ([http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/editorial/20080618TDY04306.htm in Japanese]), accessed 8 July 2008{{Dead link|date=April 2012}} ===Philippines=== [[File:Anti-Japan2.png|thumb|A propaganda newspaper clipping that refers to the [[Bataan Death March]] in 1942, which was distributed and sparked outrage worldwide.]] Anti-Japanese sentiment traces back to World War II and the aftermath of the war, where an estimated one million Filipinos, of a wartime population of 17 million, were killed during the war, and many more injured. Nearly every Filipino family was hurt by the war on some level. Most notably in the city of [[Candaba, Pampanga|Mapanique]], survivors recount the Japanese occupation with Filipino men being massacred and dozens of women being herded to be used as comfort women. Today, the Philippines is considered to have un-antagonistic relations with Japan. In addition, Filipinos are generally not as offended as Chinese or Koreans are about the claim from some quarters that these atrocities are given little, if any, attention in Japanese classrooms. It is the result of the huge Japanese aid sent to the country during the 1960s and the 1970s.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/12/world/asia/12iht-phils.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 | work=The New York Times | first=Carlos H. | last=Conde | title=Letter from the Philippines: Long afterward, war still wears onFilipinos | date=13 August 2005}} [[Davao Region|Davao]] in [[Mindanao]] had a large population of Japanese immigrants who acted as a fifth column, welcoming the Japanese invaders during World War II. These Japanese were hated by the [[Moro people|Moro Muslims]] and disliked by the Chinese.{{cite news |last= |first= |author= Herbert curtis |date= 13 January 1942 |title= Japanese Infiltration Into Mindanao |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sDRlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=R4kNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2656,1332631&hl=en |newspaper= The Vancouver Sun |location= |publisher= |page = 4 |accessdate= 16 May 2014}} The Moro [[juramentado]]s performed suicide attacks against the Japanese, while the Moro juramentados did not ever attack the Chinese since the Chinese were not considered enemies of the Moro people while the Japanese were.{{cite book|title=Filipino Heritage: The Spanish colonial period (late 19th century)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xMkRAQAAMAAJ|year=1978|publisher=Lahing Pilipino Pub. ; [Manila]|page=1702}}{{cite book|title=Filipinas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wvkMAQAAMAAJ|year=2002|publisher=Filipinas Pub.|volume=11}}Issues 117-128{{cite book|author=Peter G. Gowing|title=Understanding Islam and Muslims in the Philippines|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-H25AAAAIAAJ|year=1988|publisher=New Day Publishers|isbn=978-971-10-0386-9|page=56}}{{cite book|title=Bijdragen tot de taal-, land- en volkenkunde van Nederlandsch-Indië|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LpJuAAAAMAAJ|year=1973|publisher=M. Nijhoff|volume=129|page=111}} ===Australia=== In [[Australia]], the [[White Australia policy]] was partly inspired by fears in the late 19th century that if large numbers of Asian immigrants were allowed, they would have a severe and adverse effect on wages, the earnings of small business people and other elements of the standard of living. Nevertheless, a significant numbers of Japanese immigrants did arrive in Australia prior to 1900 (perhaps most significantly in the town of [[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]]). By the late 1930s, Australians feared that Japanese military strength might lead to expansion in Southeast Asia and the Pacific, perhaps even [[Proposed Japanese invasion of Australia during World War II|an invasion of Australia itself]]. This resulted in a ban on [[iron ore]] exports to the Empire of Japan, from 1938. During World War II atrocities were frequently committed to Australians who surrendered (or attempted to surrender) to Japanese soldiers, most famously the ritual beheading of [[Leonard Siffleet]], which was photographed, as well as incidents of cannibalism and the shooting down of ejected pilots' parachutes. Anti-Japanese feelings were particularly provoked by the sinking of the unarmed [[AHS Centaur|Hospital Ship ''Centaur'']] (painted white and with [[Red Cross]] markings), with 268 dead. Treatment of Australians prisoners of war was also a factor, with over 2,800 Australian POWs dying on the [[Burma Railway]] alone. ===Russian Empire and Soviet Union=== In the [[Russian Empire]], the Japanese victory in the [[Russo-Japanese War]] in 1905 halted Imperial Russia's ambitions in the East, leaving them humiliated. Later, during the [[Russian Civil War]], Japan was part of the [[Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War|Allied interventionist forces]] that helped to occupy [[Vladivostok]] until October 1922 with a puppet White government under [[Grigory Semenov|Grigorii Semenov]]. At the end of World War II, the [[Red Army]] accepted the surrender of nearly 600,000 [[Japanese POWs in the Soviet Union|Japanese POWs]] after Emperor Hirohito announced the surrender of Japan on 15 August. Of these, 473,000 were repatriated, with 55,000 having died in Soviet captivity and the fate of the rest being unknown. Presumably, many were deported to China or North Korea to serve as forced laborers and soldiers.{{cite news|url=http://www.mosnews.com/news/2005/04/01/japanesedied.shtml |date=1 April 2005 |accessdate=23 February 2007 |title=Russia Acknowledges Sending Japanese Prisoners of War to North Korea |publisher=Mosnews.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20061113081334/http://www.mosnews.com/news/2005/04/01/japanesedied.shtml |archivedate=13 November 2006 }} ==Yasukuni Shrine== {{Main|Controversies surrounding Yasukuni Shrine}} The Yasukuni Shrine is a [[Shinto]] shrine in [[Tokyo]], Japan. It is the resting place of thousands of not only Japanese soldiers, but also Korean and Taiwanese soldiers killed in various wars, mostly in World War II. The shrine includes 13 [[crime against peace|Class A criminals]] such as [[Hideki Tojo]] and [[Kōki Hirota]], who were convicted and [[execution|executed]] for their roles in the Japanese invasions of China, Korea, and other parts of East Asia after the remission to them under [[Treaty of San Francisco]]. A total of 1,068 convicted war criminals are enshrined at the Yasukuni Shrine. In recent years, the Yasukuni Shrine has become a sticking point in the relations of Japan and its neighbours. The enshrinement of war criminals has greatly angered the people of various countries invaded by Imperial Japan. In addition, the shrine published a pamphlet stating that "[war] was necessary in order for us to protect the independence of Japan and to prosper together with our Asian neighbors" and that the war criminals were "cruelly and unjustly tried as war criminals by a sham-like tribunal of the Allied forces". While it is true that the fairness of these trials is disputed among jurists and historians in the West as well as in Japan, the former [[Prime Minister of Japan]], Junichiro Koizumi, has visited the shrine five times; every visit caused immense uproar in China and South Korea. His successor, Shinzo Abe, was also a regular visitor of Yasukuni. Some Japanese politicians have responded by saying that the shrine, as well as visits to it, is protected by the constitutional right of freedom of religion. [[Yasuo Fukuda]], chosen Prime Minister in September 2007, promised "not to visit" Yasukuni.Blaine Harden, "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/23/AR2007092300112.html Party Elder To Be Japan's New Premier]", ''Washington Post'', 24 September 2007 ==Derogatory terms== There are a variety of derogatory terms referring to Japan. Many of these terms are viewed as [[racism|racist]]. However, these terms do not necessarily refer to the Japanese race as a whole; they can also refer to specific policies, or specific time periods in history. ===In English=== *Especially prevalent during World War II, the word "'''[[Jap]]'''" or "'''[[Nip]]'''" (short for ''Nippon'', [[Japanese language|Japanese]] for "Japan") has been used in the [[United States]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]], and [[New Zealand]] as a derogatory word for the Japanese. Tojo is also a racial slur from World War 2, but has since died out. ===In Chinese=== *'''''[[Riben guizi]]''''' ({{lang-zh|日本鬼子}}; Cantonese: Yaatboon gwaizi; [[Pinyin|Mandarin]]: Rìběn guǐzi) – literally "Japanese devils" or "Japanese monsters". This is used mostly in the context of the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]], when Japan invaded and occupied large areas of China. This is the title of [[Japanese Devils|a Japanese documentary on Japanese war crimes during WWII]]. Recently, some Japanese have taken the slur and reversed the negative connotations by transforming it into a cute female personification named [[Hinomoto Oniko]], which is an alternate reading in Japanese. *'''''[[Wokou]]''''' ({{lang-zh|倭寇}}; {{lang-zh|p=wōkòu}}) – originally referred to [[Wokou|Japanese pirates]] and armed sea merchants who raided the Chinese coastline during the [[Ming dynasty]]. The term was adopted during the Second Sino-Japanese War to refer to invading Japanese forces (similarly to [[Nazi Germany|Germans]] being called "[[Hun]]s"). The word is today sometimes used to refer to all Japanese people in extremely negative contexts. *'''''[[Xiao Riben]]''''' ({{lang-zh|小日本}}; {{lang-zh|p=xiǎo Rìběn}}) – literally "puny Japan(ese)", or literally "little Japan(ese)". This term is very common ([[Google]] Search returns 21,000,000 results as of August 2007). The term can be used to refer to either Japan or individual Japanese people. *'''''Riben zai''''' ({{lang-zh|日本仔}}; Cantonese: Yaatboon zai; [[pinyin|Mandarin]]: Rìběn zǎi) – this is the most common term in use by Cantonese speaking Chinese, having similar meaning to the English word "Jap". The term literally translates to "Japan kid". This term has become so common that it has little impact and does not seem to be too derogatory compared to other words below. *'''''Wo''''' ({{lang-zh|倭}}; {{lang-zh|p=wō}}) – this was an ancient Chinese name for Japan, but was also adopted by the Japanese. Today, its usage in Mandarin is usually intended to give a negative connotation. The character is said to also mean "dwarf", although that meaning was not apparent when the name was first used. See [[Wa (Japan)#Etymology|Wa]]. *'''''Riben gou''''' ({{lang-zh|日本狗}}; Cantonese: Yatboon gau; {{lang-zh|p=Rìběn gǒu}}) – "Japanese dogs". The word is used to refer to all Japanese people in extremely negative contexts. *'''''Da jiaopen zu''''' ({{lang-zh|大腳盆族}}; {{lang-zh|p=dà jiǎopén zú}}) – "big foot-basin race". Ethnic slur towards Japanese used predominantly by Northern Chinese, mainly those from the city of [[Tianjin]]. *'''''Huang jun''''' ({{lang-zh|黃軍}}; {{lang-zh|p=huáng jūn}}) – "Yellow Army", a pun on "皇軍" (homophone ''huáng jūn'', "Imperial Army"), used during World War II to represent [[Imperial Japanese Army|Imperial Japanese soldiers]] due to the colour of the uniform. Today, it is used negatively against all Japanese. Since the stereotype of Japanese soldiers are commonly portrayed in war-related TV series in China as short men, with a toothbrush moustache (and sometimes round glasses, in the case of higher ranks), ''huang jun'' is also often used to pull jokes on Chinese people with these characteristics, and thus "appear like" Japanese soldiers. Also, since the colour of yellow is often associated with pornography in modern Chinese, it is also a mockery of the Japanese [[comfort women|forcing women into prostitution]] during World War II. *'''''Zi wei dui''''' ({{lang-zh|自慰隊}}; Cantonese: zi wai dui; {{lang-zh|p=zì wèi duì}}) – a pun on the homophone "自衛隊" (same pronunciation, "self-defense forces", see [[Japan Self-Defense Forces]]), the definition of "慰" (Cantonese: wai; pinyin: ''wèi'') used is "to comfort". This phrase is used to refer to Japanese (whose military force is known as "自衛隊") being [[Stereotypes of East Asians#Predators of white women|stereotypically hypersexual]], as "自慰隊" means "self-comforting forces", referring to [[masturbation]]. *'''''Ga zai''''' / '''''Ga mui''''' ({{lang-zh|架仔 / 架妹}}; Cantonese: ga zai / ga mui) – used only by Cantonese speakers to call Japanese men / young girls. "架" (''ga'') came from the frequent use of simple vowels (''-a'' in this case) in Japanese language. "仔" (''jai'') means "little boy(s)", with relations to the stereotype of short Japanese men. "妹" (''mui'') means "young girl(s)" (the speaker usually uses a lustful tone), with relations to the stereotype of disrespect to female in Japanese society. Sometimes, ''ga'' is used as an adjective to avoid using the proper word "Japanese". *'''''Law baak tau''''' ({{lang-zh|蘿蔔頭}}; Cantonese: law baak tau; {{lang-zh|p=luo bo tou}}) – "[[daikon]] head". Commonly used by the older people in the Cantonese-speaking world to call Japanese men. ===In Korean=== *'''''[[Jjokbari]]''''' ({{ko-hhrm|쪽발이}}) – translates as "a person with cloven hoof-like feet".{{cite web|url=http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=36450500|title=Definition of Jjokbari|publisher=Naver Korean Dictionary|quote=a derogatory term for Japanese. It refers to Japanese traditional footwear [[Geta (footwear)|Geta]], which separates the thumb toe and the other four toes. [일본 사람을 낮잡아 이르는 말. 엄지발가락과 나머지 발가락들을 가르는 게다를 신는다는 데서 온 말이다.]}} This term is the most frequently used and strongest [[ethnic slur]] used by Koreans to refer to the Japanese. It refers to the traditional Japanese footwear [[Geta (footwear)|geta]] or [[tabi]], both of which feature a gap between the thumb toe and the other four toes. The term is also used by [[Koreans in Japan|ethnic Koreans in Japan]].{{Harvnb|Constantine|1992}} *'''''Wae-in''''' ({{ko-hhrm|왜인|倭人}}) – translates as "small Japanese person", although used with strong derogatory connotations. The term refers to the ancient name of [[Yamato Province|Yamato]] Japan, ''Wae'', on the basis of the stereotype that Japanese people were small (see [[Wa (Japan)#Etymology|Wa]]). *'''''Wae-nom''''' ({{ko-hhrm|왜놈|倭놈}}) – translates as "small Japanese creature" and has a similar meaning as ''waein'', although it is a stronger ethnic slur. It is used more frequently by older Korean generations, derived from the [[Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598)]]. *'''''[[Wokou|Wae-gu]]''''' ({{ko-hhrm|왜구|倭寇}}) – originally referred to [[Wokou|Japanese pirates]], who frequently invaded Korea. The word is today used to refer to all Japanese people in an extremely negative context. ==See also== *[[2012 China anti-Japanese demonstrations]] *[[Japanese-Canadian internment]] *[[Tanaka Memorial]] *[[Japan–Korea disputes]] *[[Anti-Korean sentiment]] *[[Sinophobia]] *[[Anti-Japanese propaganda]] *[[John P. Irish]] (1843–1923), fought anti-Japanese sentiment in California *[[Paris Peace Conference, 1919#Japanese approach|Japanese racial equality proposal, 1919]] *[[United States Executive Order 9066]] *[[Yoshihiro Hattori]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Bibliography== *{{Cite book |last=Bagby |first=Wesley Marvin |title=America's International Relations Since World War I |year=1999 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0-19-512389-1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Yns2vRoMEDAC |ref=harv |postscript= }} *{{Cite book |last=Constantine |first=Peter |title=Japanese Street Slang |publisher=Weatherhill |year=1992 |isbn=0-8348-0250-3 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=EquwgKpFs0gC |ref=harv |postscript= }} *{{Cite book |last=Emmott |first=Bill |title=Japanophobia: The Myth of the Invincible Japanese |year=1993 |publisher=Times Books |isbn=0-8129-1907-6 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QkdwAAAACAAJ |ref=harv |postscript= }} *{{cite book|title= Filipino Heritage: The Spanish Colonial period (Late 19th Century): The awakening|first=Alfredo R.|last=Roces|volume=Volume 7 of Filipino Heritage: The Making of a Nation, Alfredo R. Roces|edition=|year=|publisher=Lahing Pilipino Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xMkRAQAAMAAJ|isbn=|accessdate=10 March 2014| ref = harv }} *{{cite book|title=Filipino Heritage: The Spanish colonial period (late 19th century) |first=Alfredo R.|last=Roces|volume=Volume 7 of Filipino Heritage: The Making of a Nation|edition=|year=1978|publisher=Lahing Pilipino Pub. ; [Manila]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=akNvAAAAMAAJ|isbn=|accessdate=10 March 2014| ref = harv }} *{{cite web|last=Navarro|first=Anthony V.|date=12 October 2000|url=https://www.msu.edu/~navarro6/srop.html|title=A Critical Comparison Between Japanese and American Propaganda during World War II|ref=harv}} *{{Cite journal |last=Schaffer |first=Ronald |title=Wings of Judgement: American Bombing in World War II |place=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1985 |ref=harv |postscript= }} *{{Cite book |last=Thorsten |first=Marie |title=Superhuman Japan |year=2012 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-41426-1 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Superhuman-Japan-Knowledge-Relations-Contemporary/dp/0415414261/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1388040641&sr=8-1&keywords=marie+thorsten |ref=harv |postscript= }} *{{Cite journal |last=Weingartner |first=James J. |title=Trophies of War: U.S. Troops and the Mutilation of Japanese War Dead, 1941–1945 |journal=Pacific Historical Review |volume=61 |issue=1 |pages=53–67 |date=February 1992 |ref=harv |postscript= |issn=0030-8684 |jstor=3640788 |doi=10.2307/3640788 }} *{{cite book|title=Filipinas, Volume 11, Issues 117-128 |first=|last=|volume=|edition=|year=2002|publisher=Filipinas Pub.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wvkMAQAAMAAJ|isbn=|accessdate=10 March 2014| ref = harv }} *{{cite book|title= Bijdragen tot de taal-, land- en volkenkunde van Nederlandsch-Indië, Volume 129 |first=|last=|others=Contributor Koninklijk Instituut voor Taal-, Land- en Volkenkunde (Netherlands)|volume=|edition=|year=1973|publisher=M. Nijhoff|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LpJuAAAAMAAJ|isbn=|accessdate=10 March 2014| ref = harv }} ==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/international/story/0,,1380715,00.html China's angry young focus their hatred on old enemy] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050326094407/http://www.ailf.org/ipc/policy_reports_2004_eatingbitterness.asp The Impact of Asian-Pacific Migration on U.S. Immigration Policy] *Kahn, Joseph. [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/15/international/asia/15china.html?ex=1271217600&en=a26d8a2aa464ce14&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss China Is Pushing and Scripting Anti-Japanese Protests]. ''The New York Times''. 15 April 2005 {{Cultural criticism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anti-Japanese Sentiment}} [[Category:Anti-Asian sentiment|Japanese]] [[Category:Anti-Japanese sentiment| ]] [[Category:Anti-national sentiment|Japanese]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Japan]] [[Category:Prejudices]]

{{Unreferenced |date=May 2011}} An '''archive file''' is a file that is composed of one or more [[File system|computer files]] along with [[metadata]]. Archive files are used to collect multiple data files together into a single file for easier portability and storage, or simply to [[lossless compression|compress]] files to use less storage space. Archive files often store [[directory structure]]s, [[error detection and correction]] information, arbitrary comments, and sometimes use built-in [[encryption]].
==Applications== Archive files are particularly useful in that they store file system data and metadata within the contents of a particular file, and thus can be stored on systems or sent over channels that do not support the file system in question, only file contents – examples include sending a directory structure over email.
Beyond archival purposes, archive files are frequently used for packaging software for distribution, as software contents are often naturally spread across several files; the archive is then known as a [[Software package (disambiguation)|'''package''']]. While the archival file format is the same, there are additional conventions about contents, such as requiring a [[manifest file]], and the resulting format is known as a [[package format]]. Examples include [[Deb (file format)|deb]] for Debian, [[JAR (file format)|JAR]] for Java, and [[APK (file format)|APK]] for Android.
==Features== Features supported by various kinds of archives include file concatenation, [[data compression]], [[encryption]], [[file spanning]], [[checksum]]s, self-extraction, self-installation, source volume and medium information, [[directory structure]] information, package notes and description, and other [[metadata]]. The [[file extension]] or [[file header]] of the archive file are indicators of the [[file format]] used. Computer archive files are created by [[file archiver]] software, [[optical disc authoring software]], and [[disk image]] software.
==Archive formats== An '''archive format''' is the [[file format]] of an archive file. Some formats are well-defined by their authors and have become conventions supported by multiple vendors and communities.
===Types=== * '''Archiving only''' formats only [[concatenate]] files. * '''Compression only''' formats only compress files. * '''Multi-function''' formats can concatenate, compress, encrypt, create error detection and recovery information, and package the archive into self-extracting and self-expanding files. * '''Software packaging''' formats are used to create [[Software package (installation)|software packages]] that may be self-installing files. * '''Disk image''' formats are used to create [[disk image]]s of mass storage volumes.
===Examples=== {{further|List of archive formats|Comparison of archive formats}}
[[Filename extension]]s used to distinguish different types of archives include [[ZIP (file format)|zip]], [[RAR (file format)|rar]], [[7z (file format)|7z]], and [[tar (file format)|tar]].
Java also introduced a whole family of archive extensions such as [[JAR (file format)|jar]] and [[WAR (file format)|war]] (''j'' is for Java and ''w'' is for web). They are used to exchange entire byte-code deployment. Sometimes they are also used to exchange source code and other text, HTML and XML files. By default they are all compressed.
== Error detection and recovery == Archive files often include [[parity check]]s and other [[checksum]]s for [[error detection]], for instance [[Zip (file format)|zip files]] use a [[cyclic redundancy check]] (CRC). [[RAR archive]]s may include redundant [[error correction]] data (called recovery records).
Archive files are sometimes accompanied by separate [[parity archive]] (PAR) files that allow for additional error detection and recovery, particularly in recovery of missing files in a multi-file archive.
==See also== * [[File archiver]] * [[Disk image]] * [[Digital container format]], a similar concept in media files
==References== * [http://www.pkware.com/documents/casestudies/APPNOTE.TXT "Application Note on the .ZIP file format"]- official white paper published by PKWARE, Inc. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090611043446/http://datacompression.info/ArchiveFormats/tar.txt Tape Archive (.TAR) file format specification]- excerpt from File Format List 2.0 by Max Maischein * [http://www-03.ibm.com/ibm/history/exhibits/701/701_1415bx26.html "IBM 726 Magnetic tape reader/recorder] from IBM Archives * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120702230325/http://www-03.ibm.com/ibm/history/exhibits/mainframe/mainframe_PP1401.html "1401 Data Processing System"] from IBM Archives
==External links== * {{dmoz|Computers/Data_Formats/Archive/|File Archive formats}}
{{Archive formats}}

page.title: Bibliography of encyclopedias: business, information and economics

revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=September 2012}} This is a list of encyclopedias and encyclopedic/biographical dictionaries published on the subject of [[business]], [[information]] and [[information technology]], [[economics]] and [[businesspeople]] in any language. Entries are in the English language except where noted.
==General business==
*Becker, William H. ''The Encyclopedia of American Business History and Biography.'' Facts on File/Bruccoli Clark Layman, 1988-.<ref name="K337"/> *{{cite book|last=Bly|first=Robert W.|title=The Encyclopedia of business letters, fax memos, and e-mail|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yglFAAAAYAAJ|date=1 May 1999|publisher=Career Press|isbn=978-1-56414-375-4}} *''Business leader profiles for students.'' Gale Research, 1999–2002. ISSN 1520-9296.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Carey, Charles W., Ian C. Friedman. ''American inventors, entrepreneurs, and business visionaries.'' Facts On File, 2010. {{ISBN|9780816081462}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *{{cite book|last=Drexler|first=Kateri M.|title=Icons of Business: An Encyclopedia of Mavericks, Movers, And Shakers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iL0vtijwaksC|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33863-2}} *''Encyclopedia of Business.'' Gale Research, 1994.<ref name="K338">[[#Kister|Kister, 1994]], p. 338.</ref> *{{cite book|last1=Folsom|first1=W. Davis|last2=Boulware|first2=Rick|title=Encyclopedia of American Business|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NFFwNe11DgAC|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-0986-2}} *Fucini, Joseph J., Suzy Fucini. ''Entrepreneurs, the men and women behind famous brand names and how they made it.'' G.K. Hall, 1985. {{ISBN|9780816187089}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *{{cite book|last=Geisst|first=Charles R.|title=Encyclopedia of American Business History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dGig0fYlj8C&pg=PR10|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-0987-9}} *Gelbert, Doug. ''So who the heck was Oscar Mayer?'' Barricade Books, 1996. {{ISBN|9781569800829}}.<ref name="GtRBiography">[[#Guide to Reference|Guide to Reference: Biography]]</ref> *Gove, John. ''Made in America: the true stories behind the brand names that built a nation.'' [[Berkley Books]], 2001. {{ISBN|9780425178836}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Grace's Guide to British Industrial History<ref>[https://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Main_Page Grace's Guide to British Industrial History website]</ref> *{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Linda D.|title=Encyclopedia of Business Information Sources|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T3aK2EnVcpgC|date=14 March 2008|publisher=Gale / Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-7876-9703-7}} *Hamilton, Neil A. ''American business leaders: From colonial times to the present.'' ABC-CLIO, 1999. {{ISBN|9781576070024}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Hirahara, Naomi. ''Distinguished Asian American business leaders.'' Greenwood Press, 2003. {{ISBN|9781573563444}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Ingham, John N., Lynne B. Feldman. ''Contemporary American business leaders: a biographical dictionary.'' Greenwood Press, 1990. {{ISBN|9780313257438}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *{{cite book|last=Kaliski|first=Burton S.|title=Encyclopedia of Business and Finance|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1lcRAQAAMAAJ|year=2001|publisher=Macmillan Reference USA|isbn=978-0-02-865067-8}} *Krismann, Carol. ''Encyclopedia of American women in business: from colonial times to the present.'' Greenwood Press, 2005. {{ISBN|9780313327575}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *MacCusker, John J. ''History of world trade since 1450.'' Macmillan Reference USA, 2006. {{ISBN|9780028658407}}.<ref name="GtRGeneral History"/> *Marquis Who’s Who. ''Who's who in finance and business.'' (formerly ''Who's who in finance and industry.'' Marquis Who’s Who, 1936-. ISSN 1930-3262.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Miller, William J. ''Encyclopedia of International Commerce.'' Cornell Maritime Press, 1985.<ref name="K339">[[#Kister|Kister, 1994]], p. 339.</ref> *Northrup, Cynthia Clark. ''Encyclopedia of world trade: from ancient times to the present.'' Sharpe Reference, 2005. {{ISBN|9780765680587}}.<ref name="GtRGeneral History">[[#Guide to Reference|Guide to Reference: General History]]</ref> *Olson, James S. and Susan Wladaver-Morgan. ''Dictionary of United States Economic History.'' Greenwood, 1992.<ref name="K337">[[#Kister|Kister, 1994]], p. 337.</ref> *Porter, Glenn. ''Encyclopedia of American Economic History: Studies of the Principal Movements and Ideas.'' Scribner's, 1980.<ref name="K337"/> *Presner, Lewis A. ''The International Business Directory and Reference.'' Wiley, 1991.<ref name="K339"/> *{{cite book|last=Roark|first=William|title=Concise Encyclopedia of Real Estate Business Terms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G-3ghgUzNcUC|date=14 June 2006|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-7890-2342-1}} *Schlager, Neil, Schlager Group. ''International directory of business biographies.'' St. James Press, 2005. {{ISBN|9781558625549}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Sherrow, Victoria. Ziegler}} *''Standard and Poor's register of corporations, directors, and executives.'' Standard and Poor's. ISSN 0361-3623.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *{{cite book|last=Warner|first=Malcolm|title=Encyclopedia of Business and Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xS27AAAAIAAJ|year=1996|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-07399-8}} *{{cite book|last=Warner|first=Malcolm|title=Pocket international encyclopedia of business and management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t8SLl13k8hIC|date=1 March 1997|publisher=International Thomson Business Press|isbn=978-1-86152-113-2}} *{{cite book|last=Warner|first=Malcolm|title=Concise International Encyclopedia of Business and Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fPh0QgAACAAJ|year=1997|publisher=International Thomson Business Press|isbn=978-1-86152-114-9}} *{{cite book|last=Warner|first=Malcolm|title=International encyclopedia of business and management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=28oiAQAAIAAJ|year=2002|publisher=Thomson Learning|isbn=978-1-86152-953-4}} *{{cite book|last=Wasserman|first=Paul|title=Encyclopedia of business information sources: a detailed listing of primary subjects of interest to managerial personnel, with a record of sourcebooks, periodicals, organizations, directories, handbooks, bibliographies, and other sources of information on each topic|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DKg9AAAAMAAJ|year=1970|publisher=Gale Research Co.}} *{{cite book|last=Woy|first=James B.|title=Encyclopedia of Business Information|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L11PAAAAMAAJ|year=1992|publisher=Gale Research Co.|isbn=978-0-8103-7489-8}}
==Accounting and finance== *Pescow, Jerome. ''Encyclopedia of Accounting Systems.'' rev. ed., Prentice-Hall, 1976.<ref name="K338-339"/> *Shim, Jae K. and Joel G. Siegel. ''Encyclopedic Dictionary of Accounting and Finance.'' Prentice-Hall, 1989.<ref name="K338-339">[[#Kister|Kister, 1994]], p. 338-339.</ref>
==Banking and finance== *Munn, Glenn G. and F. L. Garcia and Charles J. Woelfel. ''Encyclopedia of Banking and Finance.'' 9th ed., St. James Press, 1991.<ref name="K337-338">[[#Kister|Kister, 1994]], p. 337-338.</ref> *Thorndike, David. ''The Thorndike Encyclopedia of Banking and Financial Tables.'' 3rd ed., Warren, Gorham, & Lamont, 1987.<ref name="K340"/>
==Economics== *Arestis, Philip, Malcolm C. Sawyer. ''A biographical dictionary of dissenting economists.'' E. Elgar, 2000. {{ISBN|1858985609}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Blang, Mark, Howard R. Vane. ''Who's who in economics.'' Edward Elgar Publ., 2003. {{ISBN|9781840649925}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Blaug, Mark. ''Great economists since Keynes: an introduction to the lives and works of one hundred modern economists.'' Edward Elgar, 1998. {{ISBN|9781858986920}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Cicarelli, James, Julianne Cicarelli. ''Distinguished women economists.'' Greenwood Press, 2003. {{ISBN|9780313303319}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Eatwell, John. ''The New Palgrave: A Dictionary of Economics.'' Stockton Press, 1987.<ref name="K339-340">[[#Kister|Kister, 1994]], p. 339-340.</ref><ref name="K340"/> *Greenwald, Douglas. ''McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of Economics.'' 2nd ed., McGraw-Hill, 1994.<ref name="K339"/> * [[David R. Henderson|Henderson, David R.]] ''Fortune Encyclopedia of Economics.'' Warner, 1993. {{ISBN|9780446516372}} <ref name="K339"/> *Pressman, Steven. ''Fifty major economists.'' Routledge, 2014. {{ISBN|9780415645096}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Rutherford, Donald. ''The biographical dictionary of British economists.'' Thoemmes, 2004. {{ISBN|9781843710301}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/>
==Insurance== *Singer, Isidore. ''International insurance encyclopedia.'' American encyclopedic library assoc., 1910.<ref name="Kr12">[[#Kroeger|Kroeger, 1911]], p. 12.</ref>
==Labor== *Filipelli, Ronald L. ''Labor Conflict in the United States: An Encyclopedia.'' Garland, 1990.<ref name="K339"/> *Jones, Lawrence K. ''Encyclopedia of Career Change and Work Issues.'' Oryx, 1992.<ref name="K338"/>
==Management== *Finch, Frank. ''Facts on File Encyclopedia of Management Techniques.'' Facts on File, 1985.<ref name="K338"/> *Heyel, Carl. ''The Encyclopedia of Management.'' 3rd ed., Van Nostrand, 1982.<ref name="K338"/> *Witzel, Morgan. ''Biographical dictionary of management.'' Thoemmes, 2001. {{ISBN|9781855068711}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/> *Witzel, Morgen. ''The encyclopedia of the history of American management.'' Thoemmes Continuum, 2005. {{ISBN|9781843711315}}.<ref name="GtRBiography"/>
==Money== *Newman, Peter. ''The New Palgrave Dictionary of Money and Finance.'' Stockton Press, 1992.<ref name="K340">[[#Kister|Kister, 1994]], p. 340.</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2016}} This '''Bruce Barrymore Halpenny bibliography''' is a list of books by the [[author]] and [[military historian]] [[Bruce Barrymore Halpenny]]. The author wrote for many magazines in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s – some under his own name and some under pseudonyms.<ref name=Titbits>''Ghosts of War'' – by Ken Livemore - ''[[Titbits]]'' – Summer Special 1984, pages 42 - 43</ref> At one time he was writing articles for up to 14 military journals around the world when he was approached by the publishers Patrick Stephens to do the airfield books due to his vast knowledge and authority.<ref>''Author wants to preserve airfield'' – [[The Press (York)|Yorkshire Press]] – Saturday, March 6, 1982</ref> Books are in order by date.
==List of books== {{inc-lit}} * ''Action Stations: Wartime Military Airfields of Lincolnshire and the East Midlands v. 2'' (Hardcover) {{ISBN|978-0-85059-484-3}} (1981) * ''Action Stations: Military Airfields of Yorkshire v. 4'' (Hardcover) {{ISBN|978-0-85059-532-1}} (1982) * ''[[English Electric/BAC Lightning (book)|English Electric/BAC Lightning]]'' (Hardcover) {{ISBN|978-0-85045-562-5}} (1984) * ''[[To Shatter the Sky]]: Bomber Airfield at War'' (Hardcover){{ISBN|978-0-85059-678-6}} (1984) * ''Action Stations: Military Airfields of Greater London v. 8'' (Hardcover) {{ISBN|978-0-85059-585-7}} (1984) * ''[[Ghost Stations]]'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-86303-314-8}} (1986) * ''Fight for the Sky: Stories of Wartime Fighter Pilots'' (Hardcover) {{ISBN|978-0-85059-749-3}} (1986) * ''[[Ghost Stations|Aaargh!: Ghosts, Mystery, Superstition]]'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-55-7}} (1989) * ''Wartime Poems'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-69-4}} (1990) * ''Action Stations: Military Airfields of Yorkshire v. 4'' (Hardcover) (Updated version with new material) {{ISBN|978-1-85260-373-1}} (1990) * ''[[Ghost Stations]]: True Ghost Mystery Stories: No. 3'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-57-1}} (1990) * ''Action Stations: Wartime Military Airfields of Lincolnshire and the East Midlands v. 2'' (Hardcover) (Updated version with new material) {{ISBN|978-1-85260-405-9}} (1991) * ''[[Ghost Stations]]: True Ghost Mystery Stories: No. 4'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-76-2}} (1991) * ''[[Little Nellie 007 (book)|Little Nellie 007]]'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-75-5}} (1991) * ''[[Ghost Stations]]: True Ghost Mystery Stories: No. 5'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-81-6}} (1993) * ''Action Stations: Military Airfields of Greater London v. 8'' (Hardcover) (Updated version with new material) {{ISBN|978-1-85260-431-8}} (1993) * ''[[Ghost Stations]]: True Ghost Mystery Stories: No. 6'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-86-1}} (1994) * [[Brother Wolf]], Wolf Preservation Foundation. {{ISBN|978-0-9524959-8-7}}. (1994) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] 7'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-907595-97-7}} (1995) * ''Layman's Guide to Protecting Yourself and Your Property Against Crime'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-9524959-1-8}} (1995) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] 8'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-1-900456-02-9}} (1998) * ''An English Town: Market Rasen (Paperback)'' ({{ISBN|978-0954777401}}) (2004) * ''[[Bomber Aircrew of World War II]]: True Stories of Frontline Air Combat'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-1-84415-066-3}} (2004) * ''Bullets in the Morning...Bullets at Night: The Italian Campaign'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-9547774-1-8}} (2004) * ''Fighter Pilots in World War II: True Stories of Frontline Air Combat'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-1-84415-065-6}} (2004) * ''[[English Electric Canberra (book)|English Electric Canberra: The History and Development of a Classic Jet]]'' (Hardcover) {{ISBN|978-1-84415-242-1}} (2005) * ''Avro Vulcan: The History and Development of a Classic Jet'' (Hardcover) {{ISBN|978-1-84415-426-5}} (2006) * ''The Avro Vulcan Adventure'' (Paperback) {{ISBN|978-0-9547774-3-2}} (2007) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] 1'' (Paperback) ({{ISBN|978-1-871448-10-8}}) (2008) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] 2'' (Paperback) ({{ISBN|978-1-871448-11-5}}) (2008) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] 3'' (Paperback) ({{ISBN|978-1-871448-12-2}}) (2008) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] 4'' (Paperback) ({{ISBN|978-1-871448-13-9}}) (2008) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] 5'' (Paperback) ({{ISBN|978-1-871448-14-6}}) (2008) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] Mysteries'' (Paperback) ({{ISBN|978-1-871448-08-5}}) (2008) * ''[[Ghost Stations]] Lincolnshire'' (Paperback) ({{ISBN|978-1-871448-06-1}}) (2008) *Ways of the Wolf, Wolf Preservation Foundation. {{ISBN|978-0952495956}}. (2011)
